title: How to get kids to listen and respect - Quora

response.answer_text: By saying things they find worth listening to. By being someone worthy of respect. It’s the same with any human. What’s confusing you is you’re cloaking your meaning in words that sound more acceptable. What you mean is, How can I get kids to obey and fear me enough not to question what I’ve ordered them to do. You do that the way all authoritarians do. It’s done through intimidation. An authoritarian makes sure they’re known to be more powerful and will to use their power to make life unpleasant for those who won’t obey. Authoritarian parenting seems to work when children are young. Children know their survival depends on their parents so they can only push back so far. Some kids push back enough to show they object, making the atmosphere in the house very unpleasant, but ultimately give in. Some kids hide their resentment, letting it build up, but go along. Some kids pretend to go along but learn to be more sneaky. Some kids accept their weakness and unworthiness and meekly obey. Where the “working” shows it’s flaws is when kids become teens. Teens are naturally wired to reject being told what to do. They need to try out their own ideas to test their understanding. If they’ve been confined to doing what they’re told often the only way they can feel like an idea is their own is to do the opposite of what they’re told, even when they know it’s foolish. But worse, all those repressed feelings of resentment of being pushed around from childhood come bursting forth. All the ways they’ve been shown how to deal with disagreement come back at the parent tenfold. Except for the meek ones. They often carry their feelings into adulthood finding it difficult to stand up for themselves. If you really want your children to listen, then you need to show them how it’s done by you listening to them. Hear them out. Make them feel heard by understanding what problem they’re struggling with. Then be their partner in finding a solution that’s safe, respectful of others, and practical. If you want to be respected, let them feel you respect them. When solving an issue together, build respect for others into the solution. Children need to feel respected first. They need to see they don’t need to choose between their needs and someone else’s. They are ways to respect both. Too many parents withhold respect until children give it. But children learn how to treat others from how they’re treated. Whatever you do to your child, however you treat them, that’s how they’re learning to treat others. If you resolve conflicts by yelling and threatening punishment, how will they ever know how to do it any other way? Children are new human beings who are still trying to figure out not only how to meet their needs but the whole lot more complex issue of thinking about how their solution impacts everyone else. Be patient, calm, helpful especially when they’re struggling. It’s easy to be peaceful when everything is going smoothly. The true test of ethics is being able to act on one’s values even when the world is in chaos. Be a listener and your children will learn the value of listening to understand another. Be respectful and help your children think of others as you help them get their needs met and they will understand the value of treating others with respect. I’d suggest How to Talk So Kids Will Listen & Listen So Kids Will Talk by Adele Faber, Elaine Mazlish. It’s an easy read full of real-life situations and practical tips. It’s been a parenting best seller for several decades. There’s also a version for parents of younger children. How to Talk so Little Kids Will Listen: A Survival Guide to Life with Children Ages 2-7 by Joanna Faber and Julie King.

If they’re not listening, stop talking. Tell them - once and once only - what the consequences will be if they don’t obey the first time (no second chances), and then - this is the crucial part - always, always keep your word. Why should they listen if you have taught them that nothing happens if they don’t?

Kids learning by imitating parents, they can notice what and who will they respect. If you are a person who is not respected you will never take respect from your kids. That is hardly true but is true. You need to be a good role model if you want to be respected, but to be not to act that role model.
By listening and respecting them. A great book is “how to talk so kids will listen and listen so kids will talk”
#1. Do what works for God! #2. Love them unconditionally #3. Take care of their needs. #4. Do not let them get to you. #5. Seek parental counseling
